bestBHT.bht: Jesus exposes the foolishness of the blind Pharisees and their false distinction between the temple and the gold. The spirit in which words are uttered is what truly matters, as Jesus had already cautioned against using derogatory language in anger. The gold's holiness is derived from the temple alone, highlighting the temple's superiority and sanctity from God. The Pharisees' focus on material possessions and their inability to grasp this truth blinds them to the essence and intention behind their words.

Albert Barnes: The temple that sanctifieth the gold - To sanctify is to make holy.
The gold had no holiness but what it derived from the temple.
It was foolish, then, to suppose that that was more holy than the temple, from which it received all the sanctity which it possessed.
Philip Schaff: Fools and blind. The distinction was foolish and false, revealing the character of those making it.
Any sanctity in the gold came from the temple, and the sanctity of the temple came from God.
Pharisees reversed the order of the hallowed things. Their casuistry is rebuked, but neither of the oaths is sanctioned.
Archibald T. Robertson: It shows that not the word but the spirit in which it is uttered is what matters.
Ye fools...here he so terms the blind Pharisees for their stupidity, description of the class.
In Matthew 5:22 Jesus had warned against calling a man μωρος in a rage.
John Gill: Who must be stupid and sottish to the last degree, and their minds foolishly blinded with avarice.
The temple was sanctified by the presence of God in it.
Whatever holiness it had, it had it from the temple, and therefore the temple must be greater than that.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse highlights the importance of the spirit in which words are spoken rather than the words themselves. In calling the blind Pharisees fools, Jesus condemns their stupidity and reveals the false distinction they make between the temple and the gold. The gold derived its holiness from the temple, demonstrating that the temple was greater and its sanctity came from God. The Pharisees' misguided casuistry and avarice blinded them to this truth. Thus, the verse serves as a reminder to focus on the spirit and intention behind our words rather than placing undue importance on external symbols.

The passage exposes the foolishness of the blind Pharisees for their false distinction between the temple and the gold. However, it is the spirit in which words are expressed that truly matters, as Jesus had previously warned against calling someone a fool in anger. The gold's holiness derived solely from the temple, demonstrating the temple's superiority and sanctity from God. The Pharisees' misguided focus on material possessions and their inability to recognize this truth blinded them to the essence and intention behind their words.

The folly of the blind Pharisees is exposed when they incorrectly distinguish between the temple and the gold. Jesus emphasizes that what truly matters is the spirit in which words are said, cautioning against using derogatory terms in anger. The gold gains its holiness solely from the temple, highlighting the temple's superiority and sanctity from God. The Pharisees' misguided focus on material possessions prevents them from understanding the true essence and intention behind their words.

Jesus rebukes the blind Pharisees for their foolishness in distinguishing the temple from the gold, emphasizing that the spirit in which words are spoken holds more importance. He had previously warned against using derogatory language in anger. The gold derives its holiness solely from the temple, underscoring the temple's superiority and sanctity from God. The Pharisees' misplaced focus on material possessions blinds them to the true essence and intention behind their words.

Jesus exposes the foolishness of the blind Pharisees and their false distinction between the temple and the gold. The spirit in which words are uttered is what truly matters, as Jesus had already cautioned against using derogatory language in anger. The gold's holiness is derived from the temple alone, highlighting the temple's superiority and sanctity from God. The Pharisees' focus on material possessions and their inability to grasp this truth blinds them to the essence and intention behind their words.
